Hey human beans 👋🏽🙂 Just wanted to reintroduce myself to anyone new around here!⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ My name is Remy—I’m 25 and I was born here in New York before my parents moved us to Taiwan 🇹🇼⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ I’m Korean, Japanese + Taiwanese (I had no idea where Taiwan was and we had never been before!). I went to international schools and learned Mandarin to get around.⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ I’m fluent in Mandarin & French, functional in Korean and pitiful in Japanese & ASL 🤟🏼 I had no one to sign to and lost it!⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ I also lived in Shanghai, where I finished high school and my parents still live. I met my boyfriend Mo 🥰 8 years ago (we’re doing #longdistance, which is why you only see him every now and then).⁣ ⁣⁣ High school was the most difficult time in my life. I hit my rock bottom with mental health. I had been struggling with Anorexia + OCD from around age 7, and by 10th grade that, along with depression and alcohol + substance addiction, took over my life.⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ I barely graduated high school but ended up majoring in Psychology at Barnard. I wanted to understand myself and help others as a psychiatrist. I also worked through all of the above in therapy 👆🏼 finally.⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ I started #Veggiekins in therapy. It was a food compliance tool, to show I was following my meal plan and taking care of myself. I recovered from Anorexia and got sober from all substances + alcohol before graduating early. I also went #vegan, which taught me compassion for animals, the environment and most importantly, myself 😌⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ I used the extra time after grad to travel for 9 months (can you tell I’m a Sagittarius lol) before starting my first job at a consulting firm but after 3 months, old habits resurfaced so I left my job to go back to treatment.⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ And now we’re here! I didn’t go back to that job and instead became a certified yoga teacher + holistic nutritionist. I get to share my love for nourishing, vegan food and high vibe living with rad humans on the Internet (that’s you)❣️⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ This community means the world to me because without it, I wouldn’t have found healing. So thanks for being here, or welcome, and stick around for the ride 🤠⁣

My college campus doctor told me something would change my life. She said: choose to medicate your symptoms forever, or choose yourself and treat the problem.⁣ ⁣ After 13 years with an eating disorder, I developed amenorrhea and with that, ALL things hormonal imbalance like constantly feeling cold, breakouts, physical pain, metabolism and sleep irregularity. She started me on synthetic hormonal birth control and when that didn’t work, we resorted to progesterone pills every 3 months to force bleed.⁣ ⁣ Only after I became tired of the unpredictable side effects of the numerous pills I cycled through did I decide to heal my relationship with my body the natural way. I listened, I rested, I gave back to it, for once. My new prescription: patience and an open mind. Oh, and an intricate chart print out that I had to use to track details of my cycles.⁣ ⁣ Much of my healing journey has been the journey to balance and making my body feel safe again. The beautiful thing is that our body is a system of cycles, and often balance comes with tuning into them and working with, not against them. @naturalcycles is like the modern day app version of the print out chart my doctor gave me--it makes taking control of your reproductive health easy and is the only digital FDA cleared, natural alternative to hormonal birth control.⁣ ⁣ Natural Cycles uses a combination of your basal body temperature and algorithm to help you familiarize yourself with your cycle, and all I can say is, if you’re feeling disconnected from your body, this is an easy way to start tuning in. ⁣ ⁣ P.S. Here’s an easy (𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 𝘦𝘢𝘴𝘺) way to make perfect やきいも or Japanese sweet potatoes 🍠⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ Baked whole it can take up to an hour (worth it!) but this is my quick, 35 min method.⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ If you’ve watched my travel packing YouTube vids you know I always pack them like this bc they last unrefrigerated for 1-2 days. They also make great sweet potato “toasts” or salad toppers👇🏽⁣ ⁣⁣ ✳︎ cut potatoes length wise, no thicker than 2-3” ✳︎ place face down on nonstick mat (I use @mysilpat but parchment paper works too)⁣ no oil needed⁣ ✳︎ bake at 400F for 20 min, flip and bake another 10-15 min until baked all the way through⁣⁣ ✳︎ optional—score after baking and sprinkle with sesame seeds or whatevaa⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ Let cool completely before storing—I usually pack them in a @stasherbag.⁣ ⁣ P.S. If you’ve never had a Japanese sweet potato, it’s worth the hype. They’re chestnutty, sweet and get an almost caramel-like flavour after you roast!

Wellness journeys often stem from a state of being unwell. Sound familiar? 🙋🏻‍♀️⁣ ⁣ I can tell you that is certainly true of my journey—if you’re new here, before my vegan/wellness journey vegan, I struggled with addiction to substances + alcohol and an eating disorder. All of these things have changed my relationship with doctors.⁣ ⁣ I saw them a lot. Post ED recovery, working on amenorrhea, hormonal imbalances and autoimmune flares, but I didn’t want fixes for my symptoms, I wanted healing (and inclusive healing! no—I wasn’t planning to stop being vegan).⁣ ⁣ Living an “alternative” lifestyle, with a mum that taught me the value in holistic healing + my commitment to veganism, I used to find doctors visits to be a mostly unenjoyable experience. I’ve been a @parsleyhealth member for a while and all I can say is, it’s a completely new experience working with doctors with a mutual appreciation for a holistic approach.⁣ ⁣ I love that I didn’t have to ask my doctor not to disclose my weight during my first check-up. I was asked whether I wanted to know, given my ED history. I’m not questioned about my choice to eat vegan, I’m supported by doctors who actually know what that means.⁣ ⁣ Currently feeling very grateful, supported and excited about healing. That is all 😌
